fields.title: Ukrainian Borscht
fields.description:
Prep notes:
- Cut vegetables to similar size so they cook evenly. Keep the beet separate so the color stays bright.
- Use low, gentle simmering for broth; boiling hard makes it cloudy.

1) Make the beef broth:
   - Put beef in a pot, cover with cold water (about 2–2.5 L for 4–6 servings), and bring to a boil.
   - Skim off the foam, reduce to a gentle simmer, partially cover, and cook 60–80 minutes until the beef is tender.
   - (Optional) Remove the beef, slice/shred it, and return it to the pot at the end for clean serving.

2) Add the “base” vegetables:
   - Peel and dice potatoes (1–2 cm cubes). Shred cabbage thinly.
   - Add potatoes to the broth; simmer 10 minutes, then add cabbage and simmer another 10–15 minutes (until potatoes are almost tender).

3) Build flavor with the sauté (the key to borscht):
   - In a skillet, heat sunflower oil over medium heat.
   - Sauté diced onion and grated carrot 5–7 minutes until soft and lightly golden.
   - Add grated/julienned beetroot, stir 1–2 minutes, then add tomato paste.
   - Pour in a small ladle of broth or a splash of water, cover, and stew 10–15 minutes until the beet is tender.
   - Add 1–2 tsp vinegar near the end (it helps keep the beet red).

4) Combine and balance:
   - Tip the sauté into the pot. Add bay leaf, salt, black pepper, and a pinch of sugar (to round acidity).
   - Simmer gently 5–10 minutes so flavors merge. Taste and adjust:
     • more salt for overall flavor,
     • a touch more vinegar for brightness,
     • a little more sugar if it tastes too sharp.

5) Finish and rest (do not skip):
   - Turn off heat. Add minced garlic and chopped dill.
   - Cover and let the borscht rest 10–20 minutes; it will thicken slightly and taste more integrated.

Serving:
- Serve hot with sour cream and extra dill. Borscht is often even better the next day after chilling overnight.

fields.title: Varenyky with Potatoes
fields.description:
1) Make and rest the dough:
   - In a bowl combine flour, egg, water, and salt. Mix, then knead 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
   - If sticky, dust with a little flour; if too firm, add a teaspoon of water.
   - Cover and rest 20 minutes (this relaxes gluten so the dough rolls thin without shrinking).

2) Prepare the potato filling:
   - Boil peeled potatoes in salted water until very tender. Drain well so the filling is not watery.
   - Mash with butter until fluffy; season with salt and pepper.
   - Fry chopped onion in sunflower oil over medium heat until golden (7–10 minutes).
   - Mix part of the fried onion into the potatoes; keep the rest for serving.

3) Shape the varenyky:
   - Roll dough on a lightly floured surface to ~2 mm thickness.
   - Cut circles (7–9 cm). Keep unused dough covered to prevent drying.
   - Place 1–2 tsp filling in the center. Fold into a half-moon, press edges firmly, then crimp to seal.
   - Ensure no filling touches the edge; otherwise the seal may open during boiling.

4) Boil correctly (so they don’t burst):
   - Bring a wide pot of salted water to a gentle boil (not an aggressive rolling boil).
   - Add varenyky in batches. Stir once carefully to prevent sticking to the bottom.
   - When they float, simmer 2–3 minutes more until the dough looks slightly translucent and set.

5) Serve:
   - Remove with a slotted spoon, toss lightly with butter so they don’t stick.
   - Top with remaining fried onion and serve with sour cream.
   - Make-ahead: freeze uncooked varenyky on a tray, then bag them; boil from frozen, adding ~1–2 minutes after floating.

fields.title: Holubtsi (Ukrainian Cabbage Rolls)
fields.description:
Prep notes:
- The cabbage leaves must be pliable (soft enough to roll) but not falling apart.
- Keep seams down while cooking so rolls stay closed.

1) Prepare cabbage leaves:
   - Carefully separate cabbage into whole leaves.
   - Blanch leaves in boiling water 2–3 minutes (or until flexible). Transfer to a plate to cool.
   - Trim or gently flatten the thick rib with a knife so the leaf rolls evenly.

2) Par-cook the rice:
   - Rinse rice until water runs clearer. Cook in lightly salted water until half-done (about 7–10 minutes).
   - Drain and cool slightly (hot rice can overcook the meat mixture).

3) Make the filling:
   - Sauté chopped onion and grated carrot in a little sunflower oil until soft (5–7 minutes).
   - In a bowl combine ground meat + par-cooked rice + sautéed vegetables.
   - Season with salt and pepper; mix until evenly distributed (don’t overmix or it becomes dense).

4) Roll and arrange:
   - Place a leaf flat, add 1–2 tbsp filling near the base.
   - Fold sides inward, then roll tightly into a log.
   - Arrange in a pot or baking dish seam-side down in snug layers (this prevents unrolling).

5) Make the sauce and cook:
   - Whisk tomato paste with water (or broth) and sour cream until smooth.
   - Add minced garlic, bay leaf, salt, and pepper.
   - Pour sauce over rolls until mostly covered.
   - Cook either:
     A) Stovetop: bring to a gentle simmer, cover, and cook 60–70 minutes on low heat.
     B) Oven: cover dish with foil and bake ~70–80 minutes at 180°C.

6) Rest and serve:
   - Let holubtsi rest 10 minutes before serving so juices settle.
   - Serve with extra sour cream and herbs; spoon sauce over the top.

fields.title: Deruny (Ukrainian Potato Pancakes)
fields.description:
1) Prepare the potato mixture:
   - Grate potatoes and onion finely (on the small holes). Onion helps prevent browning.
   - Squeeze excess liquid through cheesecloth or a clean towel into a bowl.
   - Let the liquid sit 1–2 minutes; pour off the water and return the settled potato starch to the grated potatoes (it helps bind).

2) Mix the batter:
   - Add egg, flour, salt, and pepper. Mix just until combined.
   - The mixture should be thick enough to hold shape in the pan; add a little more flour only if it’s too runny.

3) Fry for crisp edges and a cooked center:
   - Heat sunflower oil in a skillet over medium to medium-high heat.
   - Spoon small pancakes (they cook through more reliably than large ones).
   - Fry 3–4 minutes per side until deep golden. If they brown too fast, lower heat.

4) Drain and keep warm:
   - Transfer to paper towels to remove excess oil.
   - Keep warm in a low oven (90–110°C) if frying in batches.

Serving:
- Serve hot with sour cream and dill. Optional: add minced garlic to sour cream for a sharper sauce.

fields.title: Chicken Kyiv
fields.description:
Prep notes:
- Cold butter + tight sealing = butter stays inside instead of leaking.
- Double breading helps create a “barrier” against leaks.

1) Prepare the herb butter:
   - Mix softened butter with minced garlic and chopped parsley.
   - Shape into a small log (about finger-thick), wrap, and chill or freeze until very firm.

2) Prepare the chicken:
   - Place chicken breast between film and pound gently to an even thickness (about 0.7–1 cm).
   - Season both sides with salt and pepper.

3) Wrap and seal:
   - Place butter log near the center.
   - Fold sides over butter, then roll very tightly into a cylinder.
   - Pinch seams and ends closed. Chill 15–30 minutes to firm up.

4) Bread properly:
   - Dredge in flour (shake off excess) → dip in beaten egg → coat in breadcrumbs.
   - For a thicker crust: repeat egg → breadcrumbs once more.
   - Chill again 10 minutes so the coating adheres.

5) Cook through without burning:
   - Fry in oil over medium heat until evenly golden on all sides (about 5–7 minutes total, turning gently).
   - Transfer to oven at 180°C for 10–12 minutes to finish (or until chicken is fully cooked).
   - Rest 5 minutes before cutting; slicing immediately increases butter leakage.

Serving:
- Slice to show the butter center. Serve with mashed potatoes, rice, or a simple salad.

fields.title: Syrnyky (Cottage Cheese Pancakes)
fields.description:
Prep notes:
- Use well-drained cottage cheese; watery cheese makes the dough sticky and requires too much flour.
- Minimal flour = tender syrnyky; too much flour makes them bready.

1) Make the mixture:
   - Mash cottage cheese until mostly smooth (a few small curds are fine).
   - Add egg, sugar, vanilla sugar, and a pinch of salt; mix.
   - Stir in flour gradually until the dough is soft but shapeable (it should not be liquid).
   - Optional: fold in raisins (dry them first so they don’t add moisture).

2) Shape:
   - Lightly flour your hands and surface.
   - Form a thick “sausage,” slice into portions, then shape into small patties (about 1.5–2 cm thick).
   - Dust lightly with flour to prevent sticking.

3) Fry gently so the inside cooks:
   - Heat sunflower oil or butter over medium heat.
   - Fry 2–3 minutes per side until golden.
   - If very thick, cover the pan for 1–2 minutes on low heat after flipping to ensure the center is set.

4) Drain and serve:
   - Place briefly on paper towel.
   - Serve warm with sour cream, jam, honey, or berries.

fields.title: Nalisnyky with Cottage Cheese (Ukrainian Crepes)
fields.description:
1) Make a thin crepe batter:
   - Whisk eggs with sugar and salt.
   - Add milk and water, then whisk in flour gradually to avoid lumps.
   - Add a small amount of oil to the batter (helps prevent sticking).
   - Rest batter 10–15 minutes so flour hydrates and crepes cook more evenly.

2) Cook the crepes:
   - Heat a nonstick pan over medium heat; lightly grease.
   - Pour a small ladle of batter and swirl quickly to coat very thinly.
   - Cook 30–60 seconds until edges lift, flip, and cook 10–20 seconds more.
   - Stack crepes under a towel so they stay soft.

3) Make the cottage cheese filling:
   - Mix cottage cheese with sugar, vanilla sugar, and egg until creamy.
   - If the cheese is dry, add a spoon of sour cream; if too wet, add a little flour.

4) Fill and roll:
   - Place filling in the center of each crepe.
   - Fold sides and roll (or roll into a tube), keeping them neat and tight.

5) Finish by baking or gentle warming:
   - Arrange in a baking dish. Dot with butter and add a few spoonfuls of sour cream (prevents drying).
   - Bake 10–15 minutes at 180°C, covered with foil for softer texture.
   - Alternative: warm covered in a pan over low heat 8–10 minutes.

Serving:
- Serve warm with sour cream, berries, or a light dusting of sugar.

fields.title: Kapusniak (Sauerkraut Soup)
fields.description:
Prep notes:
- Sauerkraut sourness varies: rinse lightly for milder soup, use as-is for stronger tang.
- Add sauerkraut after potatoes start cooking; too early can slow potato softening.

1) Make the broth:
   - Cover pork with cold water, bring to a boil, skim foam, then simmer 50–60 minutes until tender.
   - Remove meat, slice/shred, and return to pot (optional but recommended for neat texture).

2) Start the grains:
   - Rinse millet thoroughly (it can be bitter if not washed well).
   - Add millet to broth and simmer 10 minutes.

3) Add potatoes:
   - Dice potatoes and add to the pot; simmer until potatoes are almost tender (about 10–12 minutes).

4) Build flavor with sauté:
   - Sauté onion and carrot in sunflower oil until soft and lightly golden.
   - Optional: add a little tomato paste and cook 1 minute to remove raw taste.

5) Add sauerkraut and finish:
   - Add sauerkraut plus the sauté, bay leaf, salt, and pepper.
   - Simmer 15–20 minutes until potatoes are fully tender and flavors are cohesive.
   - Turn off heat, add minced garlic and dill, cover, and rest 10 minutes.

Serving:
- Serve hot. A spoon of sour cream is optional depending on how sour you like it.

fields.title: Kozak Kulesh (Millet Pot)
fields.description:
Prep notes:
- Kulesh is a hearty millet “pot” that can be thick like porridge or looser like soup—adjust water to preference.
- Stir occasionally so millet doesn’t stick.

1) Prepare millet:
   - Rinse millet several times until water is clearer. If millet is very bitter, pour boiling water over it once, then drain.

2) Render salo and build the base:
   - Cut salo into small cubes and render in a pot over medium heat until it releases fat.
   - Add chopped onion and fry until soft and lightly golden.

3) Cook the kulesh:
   - Pour in water (or broth) and bring to a boil.
   - Add millet, reduce to a gentle simmer, and cook 10–12 minutes, stirring occasionally.

4) Add vegetables:
   - Add diced potatoes (and carrot if you use it).
   - Simmer 15–20 minutes until potatoes and millet are fully tender and the texture is creamy.

5) Season and finish:
   - Season with salt and pepper. Add minced garlic and chopped dill at the end.
   - Cover and rest 10 minutes; it thickens slightly as it stands.

Serving:
- Serve hot as a filling main dish. If it becomes too thick after standing, loosen with a splash of hot water.

fields.title: Uzvar (Ukrainian Dried Fruit Drink)
fields.description:
Prep notes:
- Rinse dried fruit to remove dust; soaking prevents the fruit from tightening and helps extraction.
- Add honey after cooling below ~60°C so aroma and beneficial compounds are preserved.

1) Rinse and soak:
   - Rinse dried pears, apples, prunes, dried apricots, and raisins.
   - Soak in warm water 10–15 minutes, then drain (keep fruits, discard soaking water if it is cloudy).

2) Simmer in stages (so nothing turns mushy):
   - Bring fresh water to a boil.
   - Add dried pears and apples first; simmer gently 15 minutes.
   - Add prunes and dried apricots; simmer 8–10 minutes.
   - Add raisins for the last 3–5 minutes.

3) Infuse:
   - Turn off heat. Optional: add cinnamon stick and a couple cloves for spice.
   - Cover and let steep at least 30 minutes; 2–3 hours gives deeper flavor.

4) Sweeten correctly:
   - When the drink cools below ~60°C (hot but not steaming), stir in honey to taste.
   - Taste again after 10 minutes; sweetness often “opens up” as it infuses.

5) Serve and store:
   - Serve warm or chilled. You can strain or leave fruit in.
   - Store refrigerated up to 3 days; flavors continue to develop overnight.
